required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Beta-blockade Reduces Catabolism in Severely Injured Trauma Patients

collaborator.agency: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK)

brief_summary.textblock: Critically injured patients endure a period of hypermetabolism/catabolism after being resuscitated. The metabolic cost of this may be measured in loss of lean body mass, poor wound healing, susceptibility to infection and long hospital stays. While there have been some data to suggest that hypermetabolism can be ameliorated in burn patients by beta blockade, to our knowledge, a prospective trial in trauma patients has not yet been done. Our hypothesis is that nonselective beta blockade will reduce catabolism, improve glucose control, blunt loss of lean body mass, decrease infections and improve outcome in a cohort of critically injured patients.

primary_outcome.time_frame: ICU admission date to ICU discharge or death

secondary_outcome.time_frame: ICU admission date to ICU discharge or death
secondary_outcome.description: net nitrogen balance, fat-free mass, and fat mass

secondary_outcome.measure: Alterations in Neuroendocrine and Immunoinflammatory Measurements
secondary_outcome.time_frame: ICU admission date to ICU discharge or death
secondary_outcome.description: blood glucose levels, insulin requirements, cortisol levels, IL-6 and IL-10 levels, infection rates, and organ dysfunction

secondary_outcome.time_frame: ICU admission date to ICU discharge or death
secondary_outcome.description: Ventilator days, ICU and hospital days, and in-hospital mortality

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ISS>25, stable at 48 hours after injury
- Fully resuscitated
- Ventilated
Exclusion Criteria Include:
- Intracranial hypertension requiring active treatment
- Hypotension/Pressors
- Already on beta blocker for a standard indication

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
